turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: Oooooh, you look so cute in your little cowboy outfit. How old were you then?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Five.

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: Oh, you look so cute as little Elvis.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: I finally knew what I wanted when I grew up.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: You know when you sat behind me?

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: At the movies?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Uh-huh, I was tryin' to think of somethin' to say to you, then I thought, she doesn't want me bothering her.

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: What would make you think that?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: I dunno. I guess I'm just stupid.

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: You're not stupid. Just wrong.

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: I love Janis.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: You know, a lot of people have misconceptions of how she died.

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: She OD'd, didn't she?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Yeah, she OD'd. But wasn't on her last legs or anythin'. She didn't take too much. It shouldn't have killed her. There was somethin' wrong with what she took.

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: You mean she got a bad batch?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: That's what happened. In fact, when she died, it was considered to be the happiest time of her life. She'd been fucked over so much by men she didn't trust them. She was havin' this relationship with this guy and he asked her to marry him. Now, other people had asked to marry her before, but she couldn't be sure whether they really loved her or were just after her money. So, she said no. And the guy says, "Look, I really love you, and I wanna prove it. So have your lawyers draw up a paper that says no matter what happens, I can never get any of your money, and I'll sign it." So she did, and he asked her, and she said yes. And once they were engaged he told her a secret about himself that she never knew: he was a millionaire.

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: So he really loved her?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: What's wrong, sweetheart? Did I do something? What did I do?

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: You didn't do nothing.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Did you hurt yourself?  Whatd'ya do? Step on a thumbtack?

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: Clarence, I've got something to tell you. I didn't just happen to be at the theater. I was paid to be there.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: What are you, a theater checker? You check up on the box office girls. Make sure they're not rippin' the place off.

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: I'm not a theater checker. I'm a call girl.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: You're a whore?

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: I'm a call girl. There's a difference, ya know.  I don't know. Maybe there's not. That place you took me to last night, that comic book place.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: "Heroes For Sale"?

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: Yeah, that one. Somebody who works there arranged to have me meet you.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: I don't know. I didn't talk with them. The plan was for me to bump into you, pick you up, spend the night, and skip out after you fell asleep. I was gonna write you a note and say that this was my last day in America. That I was leaving on a plane this morning up to Ukraine to marry a rich millionaire, and thank you for making my last day in America my best day.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: That dazzling imagination.

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: It's over on the TV. All it says is: "Dear Clarence." I couldn't write anymore. I didn't not want to ever see you again. In fact, it's stupid not to ever see you again. Las night... I don't know... I felt... I hadn't had that much fun since Girl Scouts. So I just said, "Alabama, come clean, Let him know what's what, and if he tells you to go fuck yourself then go back to Drexl and fuck yourself."

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Who and what is a Drexl?

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: My pimp.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: You have a pimp?

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: A real live pimp?

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Is he black?

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: He thinks he is. He says his mother was Apache, but I suspect he's lying.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Is he nice?

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: Well, I wouldn't go so far as to call him nice, but he's treated me pretty decent. But I've only been there about four days. He got a little rough with Arlene the other day.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: What did he do to Arlene?

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: Slapped her around a little. Punched her in the stomch. It was pretty scary.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: This motherfucker sounds charming!

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Goddamn it, Alabama, you gotta get the fuck outta there! How much longer before he's slappin' you around? Punchin' you in the stomach? How the fuck did you get hooked up with a douche-bag like this in the first place?

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: At the bus station. He said I'd be a perfect call girl. And that he knew an agency in California that, on his recommendation, would handle me. They have a very exclusive clientele: movie stars, big businessmen, total white-collar. And all the girls in the agency get a grand a night. At least five hundred. They drive Porsches, live in condos, have stockbrokers, carry beepers, you know, like Nancy Allen in "Dressed to Kill". And when I was ready he'd call 'em, give me a plane ticket, and send me on my way. He says he makes a nice finder's fee for finding them hot prospects. But no one's gonna pay a grand a night for a girl who doesn't know whether to shit or wind her watch. So what I'm doin' for Drexl now is just sorta learnin' the ropes. It seemed like a lotta fun, but I don't really like it much, till last night. You were only my third trick, but you didn't feel like a trick. Since it was a secret, I just pretended I was on a date. An, um, I guess I want a second date.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Thank you. I wanna see you again too. And again, and again, and again. Bama, I know we haven't known each other long, but my parents went together all throughout high school, and they still got a divorce. So, fuck it, you wanna marry me?

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Will you be my wife?

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: You will?

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: You better not be fucking teasing me.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: You better not be fuckin' teasin' me.

turns.text: Well, that's the one that explains how Jimmy Wang Yu became the Incredible One-Armed Boxer.

turns.text: I do.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.text: Hello, Mrs. Worley.

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: How do you do, Mr. Worley?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Top o' the morning, Mrs. Worley.

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: Bottom of the ninth . Mr. Worley. Oh, by the by, Mr. Worley, have you seen your lovely wife today?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Oh, you're speaking of my charming wife Mrs. Alabama Worley.

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: Of course. Are there others, Mr. Worley?

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: No no no no no no no no no...

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Yes yes yes yes yes yes yes yes...

turns.text: I just gotta get somethin'.

turns.text: No, Clarence. Just forget it, babe. I just wanna disappear from there.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Look, sweetheart, he scares you. But I'm not scared of that motherfucker. He can't touch you now. You're completely out of his reach. He poses absolutely no threat to us. So, if he doesn't matter, which he doesn't, it would be stupid to lose your things, now wouldn't it?

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: You don't know him -

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: You don't know me. Not when it comes to shit like this. I have to do this. I need for you to know you can count on me to protect you. Now write down the address.

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: Was it him or you?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Yeah. But to be honest, I put myself in that position. When I drove up there I said to myself, "If I can kill 'em and get away with it, I'll do it." I could. So I did.

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: Is this a joke?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: No joke. This is probably the best hamburger I've ever had. I'm serious, I've never had a hamburger taste this good.

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: I think what you did was...

turns.speaker: CLARENCE

turns.speaker: ALABAMA

turns.text: What?

turns.text: Do you want some wine, sweetheart?

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: Nope. I'm not really a wine gal.

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: You did it, Quickdraw. I'm so proud of you. You were like a ninja. Did I do my part OK?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Babalouey, you were perfect, I could hardly keep from busting up.

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: I felt so stupid just blowing those bubbles.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: You were chillin', kind of creepy even. You totally fucked with his head. I'm gonna go grab dinner.

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: I'm gonna hop in the tub and get all wet, and slippery, and soapy. Then I'm gonna lie in the waterbed, not even both to dry off, and watch X-rated movies till you get your ass back to my lovin' arms.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Ya know, I used to fuckin' hate airports.

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: With a vengeance, I hated them.

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: How come?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: I used to live by one back in Dearborn. It's real frustratin' to be surrounded by airplanes when you ain't got shit. I hated where I was, but I couldn't do anythin' about it. I didn't have enough money. It was tough enough just tryin' to pay my rent every month, an' here I was livin' next to an airport. Whenever I went outside, I saw fuckin' planes take off drownin' out my show. All day long I'm seein', hearin' people doin' what I wanted to do most, but couldn't.

turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Leavin' Detroit. Goin' off on vacations, startin' new lives, business trips. Fun, fun, fun, fun.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: But knowin' me and you gonna be nigger-rich gives me a whole new outlook. I love airports now. Me 'n' you can get on any one of those planes out there, and go anywhere we ant.

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: You ain't kiddin', we got lives to start over, we should go somewhere where we can really start from scatch.

turns.speaker: ALABAMA
turns.text: Cancoon.

turns.speaker: ALABAMA

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: But in my movie, baby, you get the top billing.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE

It'll probably be just what it's supposed to be. The only thing that's waiting for us is two hundred thousand dollars. I'm just looking at the downside.

turns.text: But you're an actor. I hear these Hollywood guys have it delivered to the set.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Yeah, they do. And maybe when I start being a successful actor I'll know those guys. But most of the people I know are like me. They ain't got a pot to piss in or a window to throw it out of. Now, if you want to sell a little bit at a time -

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: No way! The whole enchilada in one shot.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Do you have any idea how difficult that's gonna be?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: I'm offering a half a million dollars worth of white for two hundred thousand. How difficult can that be?

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: It's difficult because you're sellin' it to a particular group. Big shots. Fat cats. Guys who can use that kind of quantity. Guys who can afford two hundred thousand. Basically, guys I don't know. You don't know. And, more important, they don't know you. I did talk with one guy who could possibly help you.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Is he big league?

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: He's nothing. He's in my acting class. But he works as an assistant to a very powerful movie producer named Lee Donowitz. I thought Donowitz could be interested in a deal like this. He could use it. He could afford it.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: What'd'ya tell 'em?

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Hardly anything. I wasn't sure from your letter what was bullshit, and what wasn't.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: What's this acting class guy's name?

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Elliot.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Elliot what?

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Elliot Blitzer.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: OK, call 'im up and arrange a meeting, so we can get through all the getting to know you stuff.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: The zoo.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: The zoo.  What are you waiting for?

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Would you just shut up a minute and let me think?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: What's to think about?

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Shut up! First you come waltzing into my life after two years. You're married. You killed a guy.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Two guys.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Two guys. Now you want me to help you with some big drug deal. Fuck, Clarence, you killed somebody and you're blowin' it off like it don't mean shit.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Don't expect me to be all broken up over poor Drexl. I think he was a fuckin', freeloadin', parasitic scumbag, and he got exactly what he deserved. I got no pity for a mad dog like that. I think I should get a merit badge or somethin'.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Clarence...

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Let me handle this.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Yeah, well if we got lost, it's your ass.  Come on, Clarence, lets go. Elliot's going to meet us in the lobby.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: I'm just makin' sure we got everything.  You got yours?

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: I got the part on "T.J. Hooker".

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: No shit? Dick, that's great!

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: They didn't even want a callback. They just hired me like that. Me and Peter Breck are the two heavies. We start shooting Monday. My call is for seven o'clock in the morning.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Ah, Dick, let's talk about it in the car. We can't be late.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Clarence.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Um, nothing, let's go?

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: What the fuck did you bring that for.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: In case.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: In case of what?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: In case they try to kill us. I don't know, what do you want me to say?

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Look, Dillinger, Lee Donowitz is not a pimp -

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: I know that Richard. I don't think I'll need it. But something this last week has taught me, it's better to have a gun and not to need it than to need a gun and not to have it.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Do you really mean it?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: No, I don't really mean it. Well, I mean, this is our last chance to think about it. How 'bout you, Bama?

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Now's a helluva time to play "what if".

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: This is our last chance to play "what if". I want to do it. I'm just scared of getting caught.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Well, if we're not gonna do it, let's just get in the car and get the fuck outta here.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Yeah, let's just get outta here.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: No. But thanks.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: No thanks, my stomach's a little upset. I ate somethin' at a restaurant that made me a little sick.

turns.speaker: LUCY
turns.text: I'd fuck Elvis.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: LUCY
turns.text: When he was alive. I wouldn't fuck him now.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: I don't blame you.  So we'd both fuck Elvis. It's nice to meet people with common interests, isn't it?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Well, enough about the King, how 'bout you?

turns.speaker: LUCY
turns.text: How 'bout me what?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: How 'bout you go to the movies with me tonight?

turns.speaker: LUCY
turns.text: What are we gonna see?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: A Donny Chiba triple feature. "The Streetfighter", "Return of the Streetfighter", and "Sister Streetfighter".

turns.speaker: LUCY
turns.text: Who's Sonny Chiba?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: He is, bar none, the greatest actor working in martial arts movies ever.

turns.speaker: LUCY
turns.text: You wanna take me to a kung fu movie?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Three kung fu movies.

turns.speaker: ELLIOT
turns.text: So you guys got five hundred thousand dollars worth of cola that you're unloading -

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Want an animal cracker?

turns.speaker: ELLIOT
turns.text: Yeah, OK.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Leave the gorillas.

turns.speaker: ELLIOT
turns.text: - that you're unloading for two hundred thousand dollars -

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Unloading? That's a helluva way to describe the bargain of a lifetime.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: I grow it on my window-sill. The lights really great there and I'm up high enough so you can't see it from the street.

turns.speaker: ELLIOT
turns.text: Ha ha ha. No really, where does it come from?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Coco leaves. You see, they take the leaves and mash it down until it's kind of a paste -

turns.speaker: ELLIOT
turns.text: Look, Dick, I don't -

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: No problem, Elliot. I'm just fuckin' wit ya, that's all. Actually, I'll tell you but you gotta keep it quiet. Understand, if Dick didn't assure me you're good people I'd just tell ya, none of your fuckin' business. But, as a sign of good faith, here it goes: I gotta friend in the department.

turns.speaker: ELLIOT
turns.text: What department?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: What do you think, eightball?

turns.speaker: ELLIOT
turns.text: The police department?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Duh. What else would I be talking about? Now stop askin' stupid doorknob questions. Well, a year and a half ago, this friend of mine got access to the evidence room for an hour. He snagged this coke. But, he's a good cop with a wife and a kid, so he sat on it for a year and a half until he found a guy he could trust.

turns.speaker: ELLIOT
turns.text: He trusts you?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: We were in Four H together. We've known each other since childhood. So, I'm handling the sales part. He's my silent partner and he knows if I get fucked up, I won't drop dime on him. I didn't tell you nothin' and you didn't hear nothin'.

turns.speaker: ELLIOT
turns.text: Sure. I didn't hear anything.

turns.speaker: ELLIOT
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Do I look like a beautiful blond with big tits and an ass that tastes like French vanilla ice-cream?

turns.speaker: ELLIOT
turns.text: No. No, you don't.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Then why are you telling me all this bullshit just so you can fuck me?

turns.speaker: ELLIOT
turns.text: Get it straight, Lee isn't into taking risks. He deals with a couple of guys, and he's been dealing with them for years. They're reliable. They're dependable. And, they're safe.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Riddle me this, Batman. If you're all so much in love with each other, what the fuck are you doing here? I'm sure you got better things to do with your time than walk around in circles starin' up a panther's ass. Your guy's interested because with that much shit at his fingertips he can play Joe fuckin' Hollywood till the wheels come off. He can sell it, he can snort it, he can play Santa Claus with it. At the price he's payin', he'll be everybody's best friend. And, you know, that's what we're talkin' about here. I'm not puttin' him down. Hey, let him run wild. Have a ball, it's his money. But, don't expect me to hang around forever waitin' for you guys to grow some guts.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: He wants to talk ya.

turns.speaker: ELLIOT
turns.text: Mr. Donowitz?  I told you, through Dick.  He's in my acting class.  About a year.  Yeah, he's good.  They grew up together.  Sure thing.

turns.speaker: ELLIOT
turns.text: He says Wednesday at three o'clock at the Beverly Wilshire. He wants everybody there.  He'll talk to you. If after talkin' to you he's convinced you're OK, he'll do business. If not, he'll say fuck it and walk out the door. He also wants a sample bag.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: No problems on both counts.

turns.speaker: ELLIOT
turns.text: Where's everybody else?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: They'll be along.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Well, I guess it's about that time.

turns.speaker: ELLIOT
turns.text: I guess so. Follow me.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Elliot.

turns.speaker: ELLIOT
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Get on your knees.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Don't you?

turns.speaker: ELLIOT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Don't lie to me, motherfucker. You apparently think I'm the dumbest motherfucker in the world! Don't you? Say: Clarence, you are without a doubt, the dumbest motherfucker in the whole wide world. Say it!

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Say it, goddamn it!

turns.speaker: ELLIOT
turns.text: You are the dumbest person in the world.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Apparently I'm not as dumb as you thought I am.

turns.speaker: ELLIOT
turns.text: No. No you're not.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: What's waiting for us up there. Tell me or I'll pump two right in your face.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Yeah, I subscribe. It's a pretty decent one.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Have you read the story on Elvis?

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: No. Not yet.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: You know, I saw it on the stands, my first inclination was to buy it. But, I look at the price and say forget it, it's just gonna be the same old shit. I ended up breaking down and buying it a few days later. Man, I was ever wrong.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: That good, huh?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: It tried to pin down what the attraction is after all these years. It covers the whole spectrum of fans, the people who love his music, the people who grew up with him, the artists he inspired - Bob Dylan, Bruce Springsteen, and the fanatics, like these guys. I don't know about you, but they give me the creeps.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: I can see what you mean.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Like, look at her. She looks like she fell off an ugly tree and hit every branch on the way down. Elvis wouldn't fuck her with Pat Boone's dick.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: I don't know, Clarence, "Doctor Zhivago" is a pretty big movie.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: The biggest. The biggest movie you've ever dealt with, Lee. We're talkin' a lot of film. A man'd have ta be an idiot not to be a little cautious about a movie like that. And Lee, you're no idiot.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: But the bottom line is: I'm not Paramount. I have a select group of distributers I deal with. I buy their little movies. Accomplish what I wanna accomplish, end of story. Easy, business-like, very little risk.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Now that's bullshit, Lee. Every time you buy one of those little movies it's a risk. I'm not sellin' you something that's gonna play two weeks, six weeks, then go straight to cable. This is "Doctor Zhivago". This'll be packin' 'em in for a year and a half. Two years! That's two years you don't have to work with anybody's movie but mine.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Well, then, what's the hurry? Is it true the rights to "Doctor Zhivago" are in arbitration?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: I wanna be able to announce this deal at Cannes. If I had time for a courtship, Lee, I would. I'd take ya out, I'd hold your hand, I'd kiss you on the cheek at the door. But, I'm not in that position. I need to know if we're in bed together, or not. If you want my movie, Lee, you're just gonna have to come to terms with your Fear and Desire.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Well, I have to admit, walkin' through the door and seein' these "Soldier of Fortune" poster boys made me a bit nervous. But, Lee, I'm fairly confident that you came here to do business, not to be a wise-guy. So, if you want, I'll put the gun on the table.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: I don't think that'll be necessary. Let's all have a seat. Boris, why don't you be nice and get coffee for everybody.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Oh, Mr. Donowitz -

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Lee, Clarence . Please don't insult me. Call me Lee.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: OK, sorry, Lee. I just wanna tell you "Coming Home in a Body Bag" is one of my favorite movies. After "Apocalypse Now" I think it's the best Vietnam movie ever.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Thank you very much, Clarence.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: You know, most movies that win a lot of Oscars, I can't stand. "Sophie's Choice", "Ordinary People", "Kramer vs. Kramer", "Gandhi". All that stuff is safe, geriatric, coffee-table dog shit.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: I hear you talkin' Clarence. We park our cars in the same garage.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Like that Merchant-Ivory clap-trap. All those assholes make are unwatchable movies from unreadable books.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Now, that's practically uncut. You could, if you so desire, cut it a helluva lot more.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Don't worry, I'll desire. Boris, could I have some more coffee.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Me too, Boris.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: You like a little coffee with your cream and sugar?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: I'm not satisfied till the spoon stands straight up.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Where'd you go?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: A Norms in Van Nuys.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Bastards. That's why I always eat at Lawreys.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Elliot tells me you're fronting for a dirty cop.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Well, Elliot wasn't supposed to tell you anythin'.  Thanks a lot, bigmouth. I knew you were a squid the moment I laid eyes on you. In my book, buddy, you're a piece of shit.  He's not a dirty cop, he's a good cop. He just saw his chance and he took it.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Why does he trust you?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: We grew up together.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: If you don't know shit, why does he think you can sell it?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: I bullshitted him.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Wanna count your money?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Actually, they can count it. I'd like to use the little boy's room.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: I think there's a Seven-Up in there.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Anything stronger?  Oh, probably not. Beer? You can drink beer, can't you?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: I can, but I don't.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: That's about all I ever eat.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Go to the liquor store -  Where is there a liquor store around here?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Uh, yeah... there's a party store down 54th.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Get a six-pack of something imported. It's hard to tell you what to get 'cause different places have different things. If they got Fosters, get that, if not, ask the guy at the thing what the strongest imported beer he has. Look, since you're making a beer run, would you mind too terribly if you did a foot run as well. I'm fuckin' starvin' to death. Are you hungry too?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: I'm really not very -

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: You know what would taste good? Chicken. I haven't had chicken in a while. Chicken would really hit the spot about now. Chicken and beer, definitly, absolutely, without a doubt.  Where's a good chicken place around here?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: I really don't know.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: You don't know the chicken places around where you live?  Ask the guy at the place where a chicken place is.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Isn't she the sweetest goddamned girl you ever saw in your whole life? Is she a four alarm fire, or what?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: She seems very nice.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Daddy. Nice isn't the word. Nice is an insult. She's a peach. That's the only word for it, she's a peach. She even tastes like a peach. You can tell I'm in love with her. You can tell by my face, can't ya? It's a dead giveaway. It's written all over it. Ya know what? She loves me back. Take a seat, Pop, we gotta talk -

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Clarence, just shut up, you're giving me a headache! I can't believe how much like your mother you are. You're your fuckin' mother through and through. I haven't heard from ya in three years. Then ya show up all of a sudden at eight o'clock in the morning. You walk in like a goddamn bulldozer... don't get me wrong, I'm happy to see you... just slow it down. Now, when did you get married?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Daddy, I'm in big fuckin' trouble and I really need your help.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Look, I don't know this is pretty heavy-duty, so if you wanna explode, feel free.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: You're always making jokes. That's what you do, isn't it? Make jokes. Making jokes is the one thing you're good at, isn't it? But if you make a joke about this -  - I'm gonna go completely out of my fuckin' head!

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: What do you want from me?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Stop acting like an infant. You're here because you want me to help you in some way. What do you need from me? You need money?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Do you still have friends on the force?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Yes, I still have friends on the force.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Could you find out if they know anythin'? I don't know they know shit about us. But I don't wanna think, I wanna know. You could find out for sure what's goin' on.  Daddy?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: What makes you think I could do that?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: You were a cop.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: What makes you think I would do that?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: I'm your son.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: You got it all worked out, don't you?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Look, goddamnit, I never asked you for a goddamn thing! I've tried to make your parental obligation as easy as possible. After Mom divorced you, did I ask you for anything? When I wouldn't see ya for six months to a year at a time, did you ever get your shit about it? No, it was always "OK", "No problem", "You're a busy guy, I understand". The whole time you were a drunk, did I ever point my finger at you and talk shit? No! Everybody else did. I never did. You see, I know that you're just a bad parent. You're not really very good at it. But I know you love me. I'm basically a pretty resourceful guy. If I didn't really need it I wouldn't ask. And if you say no, don't worry about it. I'm gone. No problems.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: They have nothing. In fact, they think it's drug related.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Do tell. Why drug related?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Apparently, Drexl had a big toe stuck in shit like that.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: No shit?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Yeah. Drexl had an association with a fella named Blue Lou Boyle. Name mean anything to you?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Nope.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: If you don't hang around in this circle, no reason it should.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Who is he?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Gangster. Drug Dealer. Somebody you don't want on your ass. Look, Clarence, the more I hear about this Drexl fucker, the more I think you did the right thing. That guy wasn't just some wild flake.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: That's what I've been tellin' ya. The guy was like a mad dog. So the cops aren't looking for me?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Naw, until they hear something better they'll assume Drexl and Blue Lou had a falling out. So, once you leave twon, I wouldn't worry about it.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Thanks a lot, Daddy. You really came through for me.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: I got some money I can give you -

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Keep it.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Well, son, I want you to know I hope everything works out with you and Alabama. I like her. I think you make a cute couple.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: We do make a cute couple, don't we?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Yeah, well, just stay outta trouble. Remeber, you got a wife to think about. Quit fuckin' around.  I love you son.

turns.speaker: COCCOTTI
turns.text: Do you know who I am, Mr. Worley?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: I give up. Who are you?

turns.speaker: COCCOTTI
turns.text: I'm the Anti-Christ. You get me in a vendetta kind of mood, you will tell the angels in heaven that you had never seen pure evil so singularly personified as you did in the face of the man who killed you. My name is Vincenzo Coccotti. I work as a counsel for Mr. Blue Lou Boyle, the man your son stole from. I hear you were once a cop so I assume you've heard od us before. Am I correct?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: I've heard of Blue Lou Boyle.

turns.speaker: COCCOTTI
turns.text: I'm glad. Hopefully that will clear up the how-full-of-shit-I-am question you've been asking yourself. Now, we're gonna have a little Q and A, and, at the risk of sounding redundant, please make your answers genuine.  Want a Chesterfield?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: COCCOTTI
turns.text: I have a son of my own. About you boy's age. I can imagine how painful this must be for you. But Clarence and that bitch-whore girlfriend of his brought this all on themselves. And I implore you not to go down the road with 'em. You can always take comfort in the fact that you never had a choice.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Look, I'd help ya if I could, but I haven't seen Clarence -

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: I've seen him.

turns.speaker: COCCOTTI
turns.text: Now I can't be sure of how much of what he told you. So in the chance you're in the dark about some of this, let me shed some light. That whore your boy hangs around with, her pimp is an associate of mine, and I don't just mean pimpin', in other affairs he works for me in a courier capacity. Well, apparently, that dirty little whore found out when we're gonna do some business, 'cause your son, the cowboy and his flame, came in the room blastin' and didn't stop till they were pretty sure everybody was dead.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: What are you talkin' about?

turns.speaker: COCCOTTI
turns.text: I'm talkin' about a massacre. They snatched my narcotics and hightailed it outta there. Wouldda gotten away with it, but your son, fuckhead that he is, left his driver's license in a dead guy's hand. A whore hiding in the commode filled in all the blanks.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: I don't believe you.

turns.speaker: COCCOTTI
turns.text: That's of minor importance. But what's of major fuckin' importance is that I believe you. Where did they go?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: On their honeymoon.

turns.speaker: COCCOTTI
turns.text: I'm gettin' angry askin' the same question a second time. Where did they go?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: They didn't tell me.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Could I have one of those Chesterfields now?

turns.speaker: COCCOTTI
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Oh, don't bother. I got one.  So you're a Sicilian, huh?

turns.speaker: COCCOTTI
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: You know I read a lot. Especially things that have to do with history. I find that shit fascinating. In fact, I don't know if you know this or not, Sicilians were spawned by niggers.

turns.speaker: COCCOTTI
turns.text: Come again?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: It's a fact. Sicilians have nigger blood pumpin' through their hearts. If you don't believe me, look it up. You see, hundreds and hundreds of years ago the Moors conquered Sicily. And Moors are niggers. Way back then, Sicilians were like the wops in northern Italy. Blond hair, blue eyes. But, once the Moors moved in there, they changed the whole country. They did so much fuckin' with the Sicilian women, they changed the blood-line for ever, from blond hair and blue eyes to black hair and dark skin. I find it absolutely amazing to think that to this day, hundreds of years later, Sicilians still carry that nigger gene. I'm just quotin' history. It's a fact. It's written. Your ancestors were niggers. Your great, great, great, great, great-grandmother was fucked by a nigger, and had a half-nigger kid. That is a fact. Now tell me, am I lyin'?
